titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-1341, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel lectionary leaves in Greek. Contains portions of the Matthean and Lukan sections of the Synaxarion. With ecphonetic notation. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 40 and Ms. 939a.

headpieces.p: Headpiece of multi-colored floral, foliate, and geometric motifs at the beginning of the readings for the Gospel of Luke.

initials.p: Major initials (45-70 mm) primarily in blue, red, green, and gold set off from the text and embellished with floral and bead designs. Minor initials in red overlaid with gold.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 220 x 155 mm (fol. [1r]). Each column is 220 x 65 mm with a space of 25 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 20 lines. Ruling with hard point. Pricking in outer margin of fol. [1].

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in dark brown ink (some flaking). Ecphonetic notation in red.
Punctuation includes the cross (full stop), middle point, and the mark of elision.

textDivisions.p: Titles in red overlaid with gold.

condition.p: Leaves trimmed. Edges rounded. Occasional water stains.

binding.p: Bound by R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company in green linen over cardboard. Spine label in gilt: Four Gospel Lectionary Folios (Matthew-Luke) 13-14 cent.

origin.p: The manuscript to which the present leaves belonged is judged to have been written in the early 13th century, possibly in Constantinople, the present-day Istanbul, Turkey.

provenance.p: Medieval to early 20th century provenance unknown. Belonged to Harold Rideout Willoughby (1890-1962), professor in the University of Chicago's Divinity School. Mr. Willoughby purchased the leaves from Philip C. Duschnes (New York), ca. 1938.

acquisition.p: Gift of Harold R. Willoughby to the University of Chicago, November 1938.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: Gospel lectionary leaves in Greek. Contains portions of the Matthean and Lukan sections of the Synaxarion. With ecphonetic notation. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 40 and Ms. 939a.

msItem.rubric: εκ του κατα Ματθαιον (From the Gospel according to Matthew).

msItem.summary: Sunday, Week 11 after Pentecost (continuation), Matthew 18:24-29 (lacking, ends with και απο[δωσω]).
msItem.note: Between fols. [1] and [2], readings lost for Weeks 12 through 16 after Pentecost.

msItem.summary: Saturday, Week 17 after Pentecost, Matthew 25:10-13 (lacking, begins with εισηλθον).
Saturday, Week 18 after Pentecost, Luke 4:31 (lacking, ends with πολιν).
msItem.rubric: εκ του κατα λουκαν (From the Gospel according to Luke).
msItem.note: Between fols. [2] and [3], readings lost for Sunday, Week 18 and part of Saturday, Week 19 after Pentecost.

msItem.summary: Saturday, Week 19 after Pentecost, Luke 5:22-26 (lacking, begins with [α]ποκριθεισ).
Saturday, Week 20 after Pentecost, Luke 5:27-28 (lacking, ends with απαντα).
msItem.note: Between fols. [3] and [4], readings lost for part of Saturday and all of Sunday, Week 20, and part of Saturday, Week 21 after Pentecost.

msItem.summary: Sunday, Week 21 after Pentecost, Luke 8:5-7 (lacking, ends with ακανθων).

listBibl.bibl:
Ernest Cadman Colwell and Donald W. Riddle eds., Prolegomena to the Study of the Lectionary Text of the Gospels, Studies in the Lectionary Text of the Greek New Testament
(Chicago: University of Chicago Press, c1933), vol. 1.

Merrill Mead Parvis, The Story of the Goodspeed Collection
([Chicago]: s.n., 1952),
pp. 23-24.

C. U. Faye and W. H. Bond, Supplement to the Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada
(New York: Bibliographical Society of America, 1962),
p. 163.
